guide.introduction: Make a Minty Mouse using a Logitech m185 mouse ($16 at your local superstore). You can line the tin with electrical tape to be safe.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Make a Minty Mouse using a Logitech m185 mouse ($16 at your local superstore). You can line the tin with electrical tape to be safe.

Relevant parts
  • logitech m185 wireless mouse
  • altoids tin
  • small plastic scraps
  • optional: electrical tape
Tools
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Needle Nose Pliers
  • pocketknife

lines.text: First off, eat all the mints.
lines.text_raw: First off, eat all the mints.

lines.text: Then get a Logitech m185 mouse.
lines.text_raw: Then get a Logitech m185 mouse.

lines.text: Take the battery cover off of the mouse.
lines.text_raw: Take the battery cover off of the mouse.

lines.text: Get a Phillips screwdriver and unscrew the screw under the battery. This is the only screw.
lines.text_raw: Get a Phillips screwdriver and unscrew the screw under the battery. This is the only screw.

lines.text: Turn it over and slide the light grey part slightly up and back, till it comes off.
lines.text_raw: Turn it over and slide the light grey part slightly up and back, till it comes off.

lines.text: I have already taken the board out but I'll show you how.
lines.text_raw: I have already taken the board out but I'll show you how.

lines.text: By the battery compartment there's a tab by the white rectangle on the board.
lines.text_raw: By the battery compartment there's a tab by the white rectangle on the board.

lines.text: Push it with a small metal object.
lines.text_raw: Push it with a small metal object.

lines.text: Then gently lift the battery connectors out of their slots. Now the board is able to be taken out.
lines.text_raw: Then gently lift the battery connectors out of their slots. Now the board is able to be taken out.

lines.text: Cut a hole on the bottom of the Altoids tin about from the end of the L to the end of the I. This is for the sensor. Use pliers to bend the sharp edges flat against the inside of the tin.
lines.text_raw: Cut a hole on the bottom of the Altoids tin about from the end of the L to the end of the I. This is for the sensor. Use pliers to bend the sharp edges flat against the inside of the tin.

lines.text: Cut another hole about 3/4" away from the left side. This is for the on/off switch.
lines.text_raw: Cut another hole about 3/4" away from the left side. This is for the on/off switch.

lines.text: Flip it over, and on the "A" end cut 3 tabs, bending the edges so that each can freely move.
lines.text_raw: Flip it over, and on the "A" end cut 3 tabs, bending the edges so that each can freely move.

lines.text: Glue scraps of plastic so the tabs reach the 3 buttons. The 3rd one (in the middle) needs to be thicker or boosted with a glob of hot glue. I used old keyboard keys.
lines.text_raw: Glue scraps of plastic so the tabs reach the 3 buttons. The 3rd one (in the middle) needs to be thicker or boosted with a glob of hot glue. I used old keyboard keys.

lines.text: Tip: To make the glue dry fast, put it in the freezer for 1 minute and it'll be rock-hard.
lines.text_raw: Tip: To make the glue dry fast, put it in the freezer for 1 minute and it'll be rock-hard.

lines.text: Now take the board and align it with the holes and hot-glue it:
lines.text_raw: Now take the board and align it with the holes and hot-glue it:

lines.text: in the sides of the board's cutout,
lines.text_raw: in the sides of the board's cutout,

lines.text: beside the battery spot,
lines.text_raw: beside the battery spot,

lines.text: next to the silver oval,
lines.text_raw: next to the silver oval,

lines.text: and a lot near the cord for the sensor.
lines.text_raw: and a lot near the cord for the sensor.

lines.text: Now, glue the battery down and the contacts to the battery ONLY ON THE TOP OF THE POSITIVE CONTACT. If you glue the negative contact (spring) it will not connect.
lines.text_raw: Now, glue the battery down and the contacts to the battery ONLY ON THE TOP OF THE POSITIVE CONTACT. If you glue the negative contact (spring) it will not connect.

lines.text: TEST!
lines.text_raw: TEST!

lines.text: Decorate    :^)
lines.text_raw: Decorate    :^)
